stream_context.summary: Kaze resumes work on a side area that was intermittently crashing, diagnoses and fixes a low-level register clobber caused by an optimization. He then iterates on platforming/readability (coin route difficulty, collision accessibility), previews a plan to remove and remake a disliked red-coin mission based on playtester feedback, and reviews new Wild West signage textures made by Zeina. He also shares early concept direction for Quest 13 (ice castle) and mentions ongoing dependency on Sauraen for F3DEX3/RQIA decisions.
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a concrete technical crash fix (register misuse), a design pivot driven by playtester observation (removing/remaking a red-coin mission), and clear examples of collaboration (Zeina’s sign art, waiting on Sauraen for F3DEX3).

findings.summary: A random crash when entering the area (especially while swimming) was traced to Kaze’s optimization that stores the current object pointer in FP/S8; a called function overwrote S8 with a local variable, corrupting the object pointer and crashing. He modified code so the function no longer uses S8, eliminating the crash in testing.
findings.quote: I'm using a fucked up optimization that stores the current object pointer in the FP register, which is the same as the S8 register in GCC… this function overwrites S8… so my current object pointer gets overwritten…

findings.summary: Kaze decided to remove and rebuild an existing red-coin mission after watching playtesters; he concluded the area was "cute" but unfun due to waiting, awkward control, and camera problems. The mission will still be an 8-red objective but with redesigned layout/gameplay.
findings.quote: I watched playtesters play it and I realized this area fucking sucks… It's called Boring Red Coin Mission that will be removed from the game.

findings.summary: Quest 13 concept pitch: an ice castle on top of a mountain with a suspenseful, “scary/gloomy” vibe achieved through bright but desaturated whites/blues rather than pure darkness; boss is not decided yet.
He notes an N64 performance heuristic: overdraw is a bigger concern than raw triangle count for his environments (relevant to how he partitions geometry and chooses rendering approaches).
findings.quote: Overdraw is much more of a concern than triangles.

findings.summary: Platforming readability/accessibility pass: he adjusts a coin/slide setup because it feels too precise and expects less-skilled players to struggle; later he moves geometry to reduce the chance players climb to a spot that leads to a bad approach/fail state.
He begins splitting the reworked area into two sub-areas and checks that it still renders correctly (implying an optimization/scene-management step to avoid rendering or setup issues).
Visual integration work: he adds fog/multitexture/scuffing to a moving platform texture that looked out of place, recognizing missing fog was part of why it visually “popped.”
F3DEX3/RQIA status: Kaze is still waiting on Sauraen to make final decisions; he expects no compilation impact from the eventual change but is blocked on the decision.
findings.quote: I'm still waiting for Sauraen to make the final decisions on that.

findings.summary: Zeina produced new in-world sign textures for the Wild West hub/area (tumbleweed store, Koopa bank, milk bar). Kaze reviews them, likes the look, and calls out a sizing/scaling adjustment needed for N64 texture dimensions.
Kaze explicitly rejects doing quick UI/sign solutions in modern engines (e.g., Unity) because it undermines the core creative challenge of making content that truly runs on original N64 constraints.
findings.quote: It'd be pretty easy to do this just in Unity or something, but that's kind of taking away the whole spirit of the challenge of making something that runs on N64.

findings.summary: Kaze reiterates his workflow for collision: collision is generated from 3D geometry but he often manually tweaks vertices to ensure intended walls and avoid small gaps; he claims most invisible walls in romhacks come from misaligned vertices/corner cases rather than intentional “hole patching.”
He confirms the engine will be open source (no timeline given in this stream).
findings.quote: Will the engine be open source? Yes it will be.

biobak.summary: Biobak is cited as occasionally creating textures for levels the team works on, implying shared art production beyond Kaze’s found/borrowed texture library.

Biobak participates socially in chat (e.g., roasting Lilaa), and Kaze frames this as improving stream energy; no direct design decision is attributed to Biobak in this segment beyond general feedback presence.

zeina.summary: Zeina delivers multiple Wild West sign assets (tumbleweed store, Koopa bank, milk bar). Kaze approves them and notes concrete implementation constraints (texture resolution/aspect such as 64x43 vs expected sizing), indicating an iterative art-to-engine pipeline.
Kaze attributes his very short haircut to a home haircutting mishap with Zeina’s clippers slipping, forcing them to cut everything shorter to hide a bald line.

findings.summary: Sauraen is a dependency for final decisions on F3DEX3/RQIA; Kaze is waiting on that call before moving forward, suggesting the rendering/microcode pipeline remains a coordinated team/community effort.
Release timing of a separate “competition” project is being held until Zemos plays it on stream; Kaze wants to release quickly afterward but is waiting per that agreement.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: It'd be pretty easy to do this just in Unity or something, but that's kind of taking away the whole spirit of the challenge of making something that runs on N64.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear statement of the project’s core philosophy: authenticity through real hardware constraints, even when modern tools would be faster.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I watched playtesters play it and I realized this area fucking sucks.
memorable_quotes.context: Blunt articulation of how external playtesting drives redesigns and removals, even when an area is visually “cute.”

key_stories.title: Register-clobber crash caused by an optimization
key_stories.summary: A side area intermittently crashed on entry, and Kaze reproduced it live. He traced it to an optimization: storing the current object pointer in FP/S8, which was later overwritten by a function that used S8 for a local variable.
key_stories.challenge: Random crashes tied to swimming/entry that were hard to predict but severe enough to block progress on the area.
key_stories.process: He inspected generated code/register usage, identified S8 clobbering, and refactored/adjusted code so the relevant function no longer used S8, preserving the stored object pointer.
key_stories.outcome: Crash no longer reproduced after the change, allowing him to continue building/iterating on the area.
key_stories.key_quote: This function overwrites the S8 register… so my current object pointer gets overwritten… if you're swimming.

key_stories.title: Removing a red-coin mission after observing playtesters
key_stories.summary: Kaze previews footage of an older red-coin setup and explains that player testing revealed the mission was not fun despite being visually charming. He attributes the failure to waiting patterns, awkward control/camera, and difficulty hidden by his own skill.
key_stories.challenge: A mission that functioned technically but produced bad moment-to-moment experience for average players.
key_stories.process: He reviewed playtester behavior, identified camera/control pain points, and decided to remove the mission rather than patch symptoms (e.g., fling-vine camera). He begins remaking the area layout and rebalancing coin routes.
key_stories.outcome: The specific “boring” mission is being cut; an 8-red objective remains but will be rebuilt around better flow/readability.
key_stories.key_quote: You guys don't notice the problems… because I'm playing Mario 64 so well.

open_questions.topic: Quest 13 (ice castle) tone, structure, and boss
open_questions.context: Kaze outlines a bright-but-gloomy/suspenseful ice castle concept using desaturated whites/blues and mentions they still don’t know the boss.
questions: What specific player emotions is Quest 13 supposed to evoke (fear, isolation, awe), and what references are guiding that tone?
How will the level communicate “scary” while staying bright—through music, enemy behaviors, architecture, or narrative context?
What boss ideas have been discussed, and what constraints (N64 performance, animation workload, mechanics) are shaping the decision?

open_questions.context: Kaze references previously avoiding water due to a crash, but also highlights improved water-entry velocity transitions compared to vanilla.
questions: Was the water crash the same S8/object-pointer issue, or is there still a separate water-specific crash remaining?
What exactly was changed in the movement/physics code to preserve velocity and improve water-entry transitions, and why did vanilla feel worse?
Are per-area splash colors purely cosmetic, or do they connect to a broader per-area VFX system?

open_questions.context: Kaze is waiting for Sauraen’s final decision on F3DEX3/RQIA and implies it won’t change compilation, but it is still a gating decision.
questions: What decision is pending from Sauraen (feature scope, compatibility, performance targets, stability), and what options are on the table?
What is RQIA in this project’s context, and how does it affect rendering/content pipelines?
How are these decisions tested/validated (hardware tests, emulator matrix, performance captures) before locking them in?

open_questions.topic: Zeina’s signage pipeline and N64 texture constraints
open_questions.context: Zeina provides multiple signs; Kaze likes them but flags texture size/aspect constraints (e.g., 64x43 vs expected sizing) and scaling tweaks.
questions: What toolchain does Zeina use to produce sign textures (resolution targets, palettes, export steps), and how do you iterate once it’s in-engine?
What are the hard texture constraints you’re working around (power-of-two sizes, memory budgets, filtering artifacts), and how do they shape art direction?
How do you decide when a sign should be hand-drawn (like the milk bar) versus more “gamey” signage, to keep the world cohesive?
